answers: Bill Cunningham [or William John Cunningham Jr.]
The New York Times [prompt on The Times]
a subway car [or a train; or the motorman's booth of a subway car; or subway station; or equivalents]
parts: Name this author of Fashion Climbing. A 2018 exhibit "Celebrating" this photographer includes the Schwinn bicycle that he used to capture his street fashion photos.
Cunningham was a photographer for the Style section of this major newspaper, which didn't start printing color photos until 1997.

An iconic Cunningham image depicts fellow photographer Editta Sherman seated and dressed to the nines in one of these locations. Christopher Bonanos's biography Flash relates how Weegee first thought to develop photo negatives in one of these places after a World Series game.

answers: Arthur Less [or Arthur Less]
Pulitzer Prizes [accept Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]
Italian [or italiano] (The Story of the Lost Child is the last entry in the Neapolitan Novels by Elena Ferrante.)
parts: Identify this mediocre author and title character of a 2017 novel who accepts a series of visiting professorships and speaking gigs to avoid the wedding of his ex-lover.

Another of Arthur Less's lovers, the Russian River School poet Robert Brownburn, wins one of these awards. In the real world, Andrew Sean Greer's novel Less won one of these awards, which are named for the owner of the New York World.

A "super translation" into this language makes one of Less's novels much better received than the English edition. Ann Goldstein has translated novels such as The Story of the Lost Child from this language.

answers: slavery [or enslavement; prompt on forced labor]
Haratin ("ha-ra-TEEN") [or Haratines; or Hartani]
The Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines; or Filipinas; or Republika ng Pilipinas]
parts: Identify this practice often done in conjunction with human trafficking and forced sex work.

The Beydane ("bay-DAHN") often refer to this largest group of people in Mauritania as "Black Moors" or "Black Arabs." Messaoud Ould Boulkheir's ("mess-OOD oold bool-HAIR’s") El Hor organization agitates for improved conditions for this group.
A viral Atlantic essay titled "My Family's Slave" described the author's family enslaving "Lola," a woman originally from this country.

answers: MIT Media Lab [prompt on MIT or Massachusetts Institute of Technology]

gene drives [prompt on genetic engineering or similar answers; prompt on using CRISPR or clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats or gene knockout or other answers about manipulating genes]
Drosophila [or fruit flies; accept Sophophora; accept specific species like Drosophila melanogaster]
parts: Name this research group housed in the Wiesner Building. "Open Ocean" and "Community Biotechnology" initiatives were launched by this group, whose director Joi Ito resigned ignominiously in 2019.
Kevin Esvelt's group at the Media Lab developed "daisy" systems to safely test these things. A 2003 paper by Austin Burt proposed a natural homing endonuclease to create these things.

To limit off-target gene drive spread, researchers have proposed biocontrol sterilization with the reproductive parasite Wolbachia. Wolbachia is also a normal symbiont of this iconic genus of lab insect, whose mutants are catalogued on FlyBase.

answers: Lidia Yuknavitch
Andy Warhol [or Andy Warhola]
Chuck Klosterman [or Charles John Klosterman]
parts: Name this author of The Book of Joan who described her relationship with Ken Kesey ("KEE-zee") in her memoir The Chronology of Water.

In her TED Talk "The Beauty of Being a Misfit," Yuknavitch recounts winning a short story contest and meeting Lynne Tillman as part of the prize. Tillman's The Velvet Years is a history of this Pop artist's Factory.

Yuknavitch followed up her TED Talk with a "Misfit's Manifesto." In 2003, this author published a "Low Culture Manifesto" titled Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs that examined subjects like the Pamela Anderson sex tape.

answers: river crabs [or héxiè; accept other names such as hairy crabs; or mitten crabs; prompt on crustaceans or arthropods or other non-specific answers]
rabbits [or bunny rabbits; or hares; or leporids; accept lagomorphs]
Winnie-the-Pooh [or Winnie-the-Pooh & Pals; or Pooh Bear]
parts: Name these animals used to mock Hú Jǐntāo's "Harmonious Society" since they sound like "harmony" in Chinese. The mythical Grass Mud Horse, or Cǎonímǎ, battles these animals, which are sold live in vending machines in Chinese metro stations in autumn.

Chinese women used emoji of rice and this animal to talk about #MeToo, since their characters are pronounced "mǐ tù." A different character meaning "vomit" is also pronounced "tù," so these animals represent bulimic women on WeChat.
Chinese censors banned this franchise after memes compared Xí Jìnpíng to the central bear, with Barack Obama as Tigger and Shinzo Abe as Eeyore.

answers: universal basic income [or UBI or guaranteed income or minimum income or citizen's income or basic living stipend or universal demogrant; prompt on income or pension]
test prep [accept answers indicating preparing or studying for standardized tests or exams; prompt on tutoring]
Andrew Ng ("ing") [or Andrew Yan-Tak Ng]
parts: Identify this kind of policy that Finland also experimented with in 2017–2018. One of these policies called the "Freedom Dividend" was the signature policy of Andrew Yang's 2020 campaign.
Yang's other accomplishments include co-founding a company named for Manhattan that provides this service. This is also the main service provided by Magoosh.

Yang became a UBI evangelist after reading a book by Martin Ford. Another Ford book profiles leading AI practitioners, such as this co-founder of Coursera and chief scientist at Bǎidù, whose applied AI course at Stanford is one of the most popular on the Internet.

answers: Tate Modern [prompt on the Tate; do not accept "Tate Britain"]
oil tanks [or oil depot; or tank farm; accept Tank Shànghăi; prompt on oil facility; do not accept or prompt on "oil refinery"]
South Africa [or Republic of South Africa; or RSA; or iRiphabhuliki yase Ningizimu Afrika; or iRiphabliki yom Zantsi Afrika; or Republiek van Suid-Afrika; or similar names from other languages]
parts: One of the most famous such conversions is this large London gallery that used to be the Bankside Power Station. Tino Sehgal and Tacita Dean have staged exhibitions in its Turbine Hall.

Qiáo Zhìbīng ("ch’yao jurr-bing"), the "Karaoke King" of Shànghăi, converted five of these industrial structures into an art museum and recreation facility. Two of these structures double as performance spaces at the Tate Modern.

The Grain Silo Complex, once the tallest structure in this country, was recently converted by Jochen Zeitz ("YO-khen ZYTES") into a contemporary art museum. The Ponte City Tower was once a "vertical slum" in this country.

answers: Gretchen McCulloch

vocal fry register [or creakiness; or creaky voice; or pulse register/phonation; or croakiness; or laryngealization or word forms; or glottal fry; or glottal rattle; or glottal scrape; or Strohbass; accept popcorning]
exclamation points! [or exclamation marks!; accept bangs!]
parts: Name this Canadian linguist who co-hosts the podcast Lingthusiasm with Lauren Gawne. She tracked the rise of memes, all-caps text, emoji as digital gestures, and other features of online communication in the book Because Internet.

McCulloch has defended this register as a typical example of linguistic innovation by teen girls. Penny Eckert found that people under 40 associated authority with this register, which involves an articulation similar to the phenomenon of stød in Danish.

Teen girls have also been mocked for using these punctuation marks excessively, but McCulloch notes that they are now standard markers of politeness in emails. The brand Chips Ahoy uses this punctuation in its name.

answers: street addresses [or house numbers; or building numbers; or postal addresses]
Florence [or Firenze]
What3Words [or What3Words Limited]
parts: Identify these things that are rarely used on Native American reservations, causing problems for some voters in North Dakota in 2018. Mayors in rural France have been pressured to reform these things to no longer be based on metric distance from the town square.
This city confusingly has red and black addresses: one is residential, the other commercial. This city's Accademia, which houses Michelangelo's David, is located on the Via Ricasoli.
This London-based company seeks to reform street addresses with a geocode system that produces addresses like "tubes.page.forced" for any region on Earth.

answers: truth [accept semantic truth; accept Truth and Objectivity; accept The Death of Truth]
Hannah Arendt [or Hannah Arendt Bluecher; or Johanna "Hannah" Cohn Arendt; accept The Three Escapes of Hannah Arendt: A Tyranny of Truth]
Ágnes Heller
parts: Name this concept whose "semantic" form was defended by Jan Woleński. Michiko Kakutani's book on "The Death of [this concept]" drew heavily on The Origins of Totalitarianism.

"A tyranny of truth" is the subtitle of Ken Krimstein's 2018 comic about this philosopher, who inspired a 2012 Margarethe von Trotta film and the 2015 documentary Vita Activa. Bettina Stangneth ("SHTONG-nate") responded to her in Eichmann Before Jerusalem.

The first Hannah Arendt Award went to this Budapest School philosopher, who died in 2019. She outlined society's "system of needs" in The Theory of Need in Marx and described the "in-itself" in Everyday Life.

answers: crisis pregnancy center [or CPC; or pregnancy resource center; or PRC] (The case was Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt.)
Texas [or TX]
TRAP Laws [accept targeted restrictions on abortion providers]
parts: Identify these non-profits that are often tied to larger groups like Care Net and Heartbeat International. They commonly offer free sonograms to discourage women from having abortions.
Miller's Whole Woman's Health abortion clinic was in the capital of this state. Wendy Davis filibustered an anti-abortion bill in this state before running against Greg Abbott for governor.
Pro-life advocates have passed several laws known by this four-letter acronym that make it harder to run abortion clinics by, for example, requiring clinics to qualify as surgery centers.

answers: magnetoreception [or magnetoception; or magnetosensing; accept anything about sensing Earth's magnetic field or magnetism]
protein crystallization [or word forms like getting a crystal structure; accept X-ray crystallography]
foveated imaging systems [or word forms; accept fovea centralis]
parts: Sheldrake has asserted that homing pigeons have collective memory. A contentious 2015 Nature Materials paper claimed to discover the cryptochrome complex that controls this sense that they use for homing.

Sheldrake used "morphogenesis" to try to explain why this task gets easier over time. This frustrating process involves supersaturating a pure protein sample to obtain an X-ray image of its structure.

Sheldrake claims that people sense they are being stared at with "morphic resonance." Real research on eye movements has contributed to these imaging systems, which save bandwidth by decreasing resolution as a function of eccentricity to mimic the human eye.

answers: The Band's Visit
Tel Aviv [accept Gush Dan]
Ireland [or Republic of Ireland; or Éire; or Poblacht na hÉireann] (The singer was Brendan Graham.)
parts: Name this musical whose song "Welcome to Nowhere" distinguishes between a city with "lots of fun, lots of art, lots of culture" "with a P" and a similar-sounding town "with a B" that is "basically bleak and beige."

The fun city alluded to in The Band's Visit, Petah Tikva ("PET-ahkh TICK-va"), lies in the metro area of this city. After Netta's song "Toy" won Eurovision in 2018, the 2019 contest was held in this Israeli cultural capital.

The Tel Aviv Eurovision was protested by a singer from this country who won it in 1994 for "Rock 'n' Roll Kids." This country's "shoegazing" band My Bloody Valentine developed the "glide guitar" technique.

answers: white-nose syndrome [or WNS]
Pinnacles National Park
Indiana [or IN; accept Indiana Dunes National Park]
parts: Name this disease that can be treated by the bacterium Rhodococcus. This disease has devastated bats infected by the psychrophilic fungus Pseudogymnoascus destructans ("pseudo-gymno-ascus destruct-ans").

White-nose syndrome has luckily not spread to this national park, where many bats inhabit unique talus caves. This national park supports hundreds of bee species and provides a key release site for California condor recovery.

Pinnacles became a national park six years before this state's sand dunes on Lake Michigan. The Lucas Oil Stadium and Artsgarden were recently built in this state's capital, which hosts an annual motorsports race.

answers: Words Without Borders [or WWB]
México [or Estados Unidos Mexicanos; or United Mexican States]
Gothic novels [accept Mexican Gothic; accept Southern Gothic or Southern Ontario Gothic]
parts: Name this online magazine for literature in translation. This magazine's monthly themed issues have included "Dalit Literature in Hindi" and "Contemporary Guaraní Poetry."

Carmen Boullosa ("bo-YO-sa") edited an issue of Words Without Borders about a conflict in this country. Valeria Luiselli wrote The Story of My Teeth in collaboration with a juice factory in this country, where Jorge Volpi contributed to the "Crack Manifesto."

A 2020 novel by Silvia Moreno-Garcia takes place in a '50s-era Mexico inflected by this genre. The "Southern Ontario" style of this genre plays on its "Southern" subgenre attributed to Carson McCullers.

answers: mass school shootings [prompt on mass shootings or murders or massacres]
Jack Thompson [or John Bruce Thompson]
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [or CDC]
parts: Identify these tragic events. A 2002 Michael Moore documentary explored what caused Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold to carry out one of these actions.

This now-disbarred lawyer sued the producers of 1997's The Basketball Diaries for supposedly causing Michael Carneal to shoot up a prayer group. In 2007, TakeTwo tried to prevent this man from suing the company over Grand Theft Auto.
This organization, led during much of the Trump era by Robert Redfield, was barred from doing research on gun control via the 1996 Dickey Amendment.

answers: Microsoft PowerPoint [prompt on Microsoft Office]
An Inconvenient Truth (The song was Melissa Etheridge's "I Need to Wake Up.")
David Byrne ("burn")
parts: Identify this software, the most popular in a category that also includes Prezi and Keynote.
In several scenes of this documentary, the protagonist can be seen revising his slides in Keynote. This documentary, which was produced by Laurie David, unusually won an Oscar for Best Original Song.

In 2005, this artist gave a somewhat sarcastic talk at Berkeley titled "I Love PowerPoint." This artist discussed how the acoustics of nightclubs influenced the sound of rock music in his 2012 book How Music Works.

answers: Python [accept iPython]
conda [or Anaconda; accept Miniconda]
pip [or pip installs packages]
parts: Name this programming language whose "benevolent dictator for life," Guido van Rossum, stepped down in 2018. Data scientists have widely adopted the pandas library for this language, which students often learn with the environment IDLE.
Data scientists often use packages from this Python and R distribution. Users can make a virtual environment by typing this package manager's name followed by "create."

Conda's install tool is an alternative to this popular command-line Python package installer system whose short name is a recursive acronym. It's common to use a "requirements.txt" file with this tool.

answers: Peru [or Republic of Peru; or República del Perú]
Keiko Fujimori [or Keiko Sofía Fujimori Higuchi; or Señora K]
Odebrecht S.A.
parts: Name this country whose exiled former President Alejandro Toledo was arrested in California for public intoxication in 2019. In that same year, another of its former presidents committed suicide.
Peruvian prosecutors arrested this ex-First Lady in 2018 on money laundering charges. Her father, a former President, fled to Japan to try to beat human rights charges.

Keiko Fujimori is one of many Peruvian politicians alleged to have taken bribes from this Brazilian conglomerate. Marcelo, a member of this company's eponymous family, was arrested in Operation Car Wash.
